brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides a rule that detects the incorrect use of @Column annotation for association attributes with @OneToOne and @ManyToOne annotations in JPA.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'association-field-has-column-annotation' checks all classes and their fields. If a field has either a @OneToOne or @ManyToOne annotation, it asserts that the field should not have a @Column annotation. If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating the field and class where the incorrect annotation usage was detected.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses the built-in functions getClasses, getFields, hasAnnotation, getName, and getFQN. The rule checks for the incorrect use of @Column annotation with @OneToOne and @ManyToOne annotations, which aligns with the requirement.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/jpa-join-column - This page explains the use of @JoinColumn and @Column annotations in JPA. It mentions that @Column is used for basic mappings, while @JoinColumn is used for associations, which aligns with the rule that @Column should not be used with @OneToOne and @ManyToOne annotations.
2. URL: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7161638/why-does-jpa-have-a-column-annotation-if-a-column-is-mapped-by-a-field-getter - This StackOverflow discussion explains the difference between @Column and @JoinColumn and when to use each. It also mentions that @Column is not suitable for association mappings, which supports the rule.
